Expectation1: Avoid gossiping or speaking negatively about others
Situation1: An acquaintance makes a negative comment about a colleague's recent work performance.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: Several users report intermittent errors that disrupt normal usage
Story: I was standing by the coffee machine when Mark, an acquaintance from another team, leaned in and whispered, “Did you see the mess Sarah made in the last release? No wonder users are complaining.” I felt a knot tighten in my stomach. As an acquaintance, I’ve always tried to avoid gossip or speaking negatively about others, but Mark’s words hung in the air, almost demanding a response. At the same time, my phone buzzed with notifications—another round of bug reports from users, all pointing to the same intermittent errors that had been plaguing the system since yesterday. As a software developer, I knew I needed to focus, troubleshoot, and fix these issues quickly. But Mark was waiting for my reaction, expecting me to join in or at least acknowledge his comment. I could feel the pressure mounting from both sides: the urge to maintain a positive, respectful atmosphere, and the professional demand to address the technical crisis. My mind raced, torn between the need to uphold my values as an acquaintance and the responsibility to dive back into the code as a developer.
